speaker: Shaama M. Sharada
transcript: To to Julia's point actually about about finding large scale applications for CO2. I think we can do several small scale applications if we think big enough right? There's a wealth of literature on organic synthesis where you can think of CO2 as a feedstock for carboxylation reactions of anything to produce anything from specialty chemicals to pharmaceutical ingredients. And there's a mix of pathways to be able to do that either using like any synthetic organic chemistry or or photoredox pathways where you have these nice organic or inorganic photoredox catalysts that either in their excited states or in some sort of anion radical states can reduce CO2 and and help carboxylate things like styrene carboxylation amino acid formation. So I think there are a lot of little niche applications that we can come up with based on on the chemical knowledge that we already have. And are there some really interesting science challenges that would make those reaction could make those reactions much more efficient or less energy intensive or are there some that would help scale them commercially and make them cost effective?

speaker: Rafael Santos
transcript: I just wanted to give one more example of a large scale application which would be uh mining tailings right so then I go back to the idea of if you have a uh transportable direct air capture unit you can transport it to a place that has mining tailings and some mining tailings actually exist right beside an industry still emitting CO2 so then it might make sense to more again use the CO2 from the flue gas but a lot of mining tailings are in old mining sites where there's nothing anymore there there are cities which even don't exist anymore and the mining tailings are still there. So you could take your direct air capture there unit there capture CO2 and then inject it into the mining tailings to then do mineral carbonation of the mining tailings right so this is a well accepted idea many people in Canada Australia and so on work on this but they usually assume that they're getting the CO2 directly from the air but if we can capture the CO2 and concentrate it then we're going to be weathering those tailings a lot faster and maybe even more than just by by waiting for the the air to do it so that would be a large scale potential application.

speaker: Jen Wilcox
transcript: So one of the mechanisms and I don't know Raphael I heard you might work in mineralization. So one of the things that it's known to be able to do is help to bring the magnesium out of you know so if you have a a mine tailing waste and it's got magnesium in it often times the magnesium isn't necessarily reactive because it's bound in a silica structure and it's very difficult to get it out. But when you add oxalate or or oxalic acid to the solution it actually helps to dissolve the magnesium and make it reactive for crystallization and mineralization with CO2. And so one of the things like the Opus 12 was looking at is working with a company called Solidia and so very different but looking at Solidia's process I don't know if you guys know Solidia is a company where they make low carbon concrete ultimately. And so one process in which they do that instead of curing with water they cure with CO2. And it turns out that if you add oxalic acid in that process you enhance the uptake of CO2 through the curing process. And so really it's it's like you know that acid allows the magnesium atoms in your feedstock if it's a mineralization approach to be more reactive to CO2 and to help bind it but it's towards a permanent product not necessarily like like you wouldn't use it as a a fuel you would use it as a part of an enhancement process for mineralizing CO2. So that's how I see it
screenshare_content: The Google Doc titled "Feedstocks" remains shared on the screen. No changes are made to the content.

speaker: Julia Brown
transcript: I wonder who we haven't heard from for a little while. Sharma. What are your thoughts at the moment?
screenshare_content: The Google Doc titled "Feedstocks" remains shared on the screen. No changes are made to the content.

speaker: Shaama M. Sharada
transcript: Sorry. Yeah. At least based on my understanding of the ways in which we can convert CO2, I know there's a huge push towards electrochemistry because there is that's one sustainable way of leveraging solar and wind to convert to electricity and then use that towards reducing CO2. One of the things that is kind of less explored at least based on my understanding is using light directly. So one of the things that you can achieve with light which is difficult to achieve in an electrochemical process is the one electron reduction of CO2. When you talk about electrochemistry you're talking about two or more electron reduction of CO2 right because one electron has a very very high over potential associated with it. So those kind of reductions can be achieved using photo redox chemistry. So essentially using light to drive a photo redox catalyst to become an anion and that anion can push one electron towards CO2. And as far as I understand it there are operational issues associated with it which is why as of right now it's mostly focused on highly specific applications. It could either be things like adding COOH groups to aromatics so basically carboxylate styrene and make a polymer precursor. Attach a carboxylic acid to an amine and make an amino acid which can go into pharmaceuticals. So there are a lot of specialized applications that we can think of. The challenge of course being making sure that these catalysts are cyclable and coming up with continuous processes. But at least there are lab scale continuous processes that exist now that leverage these light assisted pathways. So I think we can do more difficult chemistry as well beyond what is shown with electrocatalysis and we can think beyond formic acid right because you can use any kind of substrate and link a carboxylate group to it.
screenshare_content: A document is being shared on the screen, which appears to be a collaborative document like Google Docs. The document has a title and some numbered points related to the discussion topics. The content is static during this segment.
other: The speaker uses frequent hand gestures to explain complex chemical processes.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing ideas about CO2 conversion by introducing photo-redox chemistry as an alternative approach to electrochemistry.

speaker: Julia Brown
transcript: Are there some exciting in particular exciting challenges that that we need some more research in in that area something that
screenshare_content: The same collaborative document remains on the screen with no changes made.

speaker: Shaama M. Sharada
transcript: Yeah so one of the issues that that I see with some of the catalysts that we look at is the cyclability. Because you're using light in addition to doing the photo redox chemistry these molecules tend to degrade rather rapidly. So you get five turnovers and everything dies out. And this is and the issues are I think kind of common between the materials used for catalysis and the materials we use for organic LEDs for example. So I think there is a lot of opportunity in trying to identify what those degradation pathways are and finding ways to mitigate them and that has applications across all kinds of light all kinds of photonic materials not just photo redox chemistry.
screenshare_content: The same collaborative document remains on the screen with no changes made.

speaker: andrea hicks
transcript: So some of my background's in sustainability. So it's a slightly different take. I mean the one thing I think about whenever we talk about steps is that every step or raw material or energy or electricity consumption adds environmental impact as does transportation. So it's just being careful that you know although a process may be easy and feasible at some point it actually won't be better from a carbon standpoint depending on what you use. And that's just one thing to think about that I was thinking about as people were talking. You know and one other thing that struck me Julia I think way at the beginning you talked about growing plants with carbon dioxide and it actually reminded me so we work with in my other research hats with an aquaponics producer. So aquaponics is hydroponically grown plants aquaculture no soil you cycle nutrients lower environmental impacts. And they're actually using carbon dioxide that's not waste carbon dioxide and pumping it into their greenhouse right now to bring up their yields. So I was thinking a little bit more about the distributed systems that you could do as we seek to feed more of the world that you know if we are increasing aquaponics which it seems like we are you know what are some unconventional places we haven't thought as much about using CO2 because we think they're niche right now but they might not end up being. I think we've got one of the bigger ones in the country that's doing I think almost 200,000 pounds of fish a year and fills up at least like a truck a day like one of those big delivery trucks a day of greens. But that's my two cents.
